awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Transfer by Contact using Adhesion Engineering for Integration of Two-Dimensional Materials into Functional Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
The discovery of graphene has led to the discovery of atomically thin two-dimensional materials with diverse and unique properties. Two-dimensional materials have rapidly grown into one of the leading material platforms for next-generation electronics, optoelectronics and quantum devices. For these materials to be integrated into functional devices, they need to be isolated from their growth substrate and transferred onto a target surface without damage and contamination. This materials integration is challenging to achieve through the current transfer techniques which generally rely on wet and high temperature processes using additional support layers. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project looks to overcome these challenges by developing and understanding a dry and low-temperature process that allows direct transfer of two-dimensional materials from a source to target by a single direct contact and delamination step without a need for a support layer. Such a technique can help reduce damage and contamination during the transfer to achieve otherwise hard to realize structures in a scalable and high-throughput manner. As a result, this transfer platform can help in promoting our nation’s global competitiveness in the rapidly evolving field of two-dimensional materials and their applications. This research program will provide opportunities for training students in this area. The results of this research will be directly integrated as a laboratory teaching module in a new course being developed.   

The aim of this research is to develop a dry, low-temperature, sacrificial layer-free transfer of monolayer two-dimensional materials. In this approach, transfer occurs as the source and target surfaces are brought into contact and delaminated under controlled conditions using an aligned transfer printing platform. Foundational to this is engineering of the target substrate surface with interactions and adhesion mechanisms beyond van der Waals forces that promote a successful transfer. This EAGER will develop this approach for 2D monolayer transfer with a focus on surface adhesion engineering through tuning the surface chemical terminations and mechanical characteristics, studying the adhesion mechanisms, probing the transfer quality and accordingly optimizing for a damage and contamination-free transfer.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Two-dimensional (2D) materials, with diverse unconventional properties, have emerged as a promising platform for the next-generation electronic and optoelectronic devices. Leveraging these properties requires 2D materials integration into pristine functional heterostructures. With atomic dimensions and susceptible to damage, however, conventional fabrication techniques are often insufficient for 2D material processing. To this end, heterogeneous integration of 2D and other materials using van der Waals (vdW) forces have been widely investigated where different materials can be physically stacked through a transfer process, even if chemically incompatible. Dependent on intrinsic materials properties, however, vdW forces are weak and not readily tunable to accommodate integration of arbitrary layers which is core to the development of functional devices. To this end, conventional techniques often rely on sacrificial layers, solvents, high-temperatures and surface coatings to promote the transfer which can introduce damage, contaminants and alter the desired properties. To address this limitation and extend vdW integration beyond the physical limits of vdW forces, we have developed the adhesive matrix transfer. In our approach, the forces inducing the transfer are decoupled from the vdW forces forming the heterostructure of interest by utilizing an adhesive matrix with tailorable interactions surrounding the desired surface. By doing so, we have demonstrated conventionally-forbidden direct integration of diverse 2D materials (MoS2, WSe2, PtS2, GaS) with dielectrics (SiO2, Al2O3), and shown the technique's compatibility with scalable and aligned heterostructure processing. Using this technique, we have demonstrated single-step 2D material-to-device integration where, as an example, we have developed arrays of MoS2 transistors on rigid and flexible substrates. As polymers, solvents and high-temperatures are avoided, the resulting heterostructures and surfaces can remain pristine and intrinsic properties maintained intact. Such a technique extends the rapidly growing applications of vdW integration for 2D material studies and device implementation. The impact of this work though is beyond 2D materials and extends to other material systems incompatible with the conventional growth and fabrication processes. As an example, we have demonstrated the intricate engineering of nanoscale forces to allow for dry vdW integration of spatially arranged nanoparticles onto arbitrary surfaces including forming nanoparticle-on-2D material heterostructures. The newly developed vdW integration strategies also provide new and widely accessible educational opportunities to integrate hands-on experiences with emerging nanomaterials and devices within academic curricula as the processes can be easily implemented at low cost without a need for extended training and traditionally complex fabrication tools. To this end, we have utilized such techniques to incorporate a hands-on experience with fabrication and characterization of 2D material transistors in an undergraduate course. These platforms generate opportunities for education and workforce development for emerging nanotechnologies accessible to diverse communities.  

 


Last Modified: 03/29/2023
Modified by: Farnaz Niroui
